metaData.descriptionCS: Young examinees trace and copy letters, and write letters, words, and sentences from dictation. Older examinees write sentences from dictation, add capitalization and punctuation, complete or combine sentences, and write an essay.

questions.title: Introduction
Item 1. Write name
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Open the Response Booklet to the Written Expression page and place it in front of the examinee.

Write your first and last name here (point).

criteria.guidelines:
Disregard capitalization, minor spelling errors, and letter reversals.

To be considered phonetically readable, the examinee’s name must contain more than a single letter.

2 points: phonetically readable first and last name

Hannah (1) Larsen (1)

Sam (1) Hong (1)

Josie (1) Martins (1)

Travis (1) Rylander (1)

Maria (1) Olson (1)

​

  

1 point: phonetically readable first or last name only

Alysha (1)

Vincent (1)

0 points: neither first nor last name is phonetically readable

Ashton (0)

Bernardo (0)

Augustine (0)

​
criteria.title: Write name

data.generalScoringContent:
Scoring Rationale

Written Expression at Level 1 is designed to assess the examinee’s ability to write his or her name, trace letters, copy letters, and write dictated letters and words. Spelling is not scored.

Scoring Guidelines for Phonetically Readable Words

Phonetically readable is not a technical term; it means that all sounds in the word are represented and in the correct sequence even if the word is not spelled correctly. Missing letters, poor letter formation, letter reversals, and upside-down or sideways letters are acceptable as long as the word is recognizable.

Scoring Guidelines for Recognizable Letters

Poor letter formation, letter reversals, and upside-down or sideways letters are acceptable as long as the letter is recognizable and does not form another letter. Accept upper- or lowercase letters or a mix.

questions.title: Item 2. Trace letters: S, h, o
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
This word is School. Some letters are missing.
Write S here (point to dotted S).
Write h here (point to dotted h).
Write o here (point to dotted o).

criteria.guidelines:
The letters must be recognizable, but do not need to be traced along the dashed lines.

3 points: three traced letters are recognizable

S (1), h (1), o (1)

2 points: two traced letters are recognizable

S (1), h (1), o (0)

1 point: one traced letter is recognizable

S (0), h (0), o (1)

​

0 points: no traced letters are recognizable

S (0), h (0), o (0)

​​
criteria.title: Trace letters (1 point for each letter)

questions.title: Item 14. Write two dictated words: old hat
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
He wears an old hat. Write the words old hat (point to both lines next to 14; there is a space for each word).

If the examinee writes only one word, say, Write both words. Listen: old hat.

criteria.guidelines:
A clear space is required between the two words. If the examinee’s response would not be recognized as two separate words out of context, score 0 points for both words.

Do not penalize for unnecessary capitalization or punctuation.

1 point: phonetically readable

0 points: not phonetically readable

old (1) hat (1)

old (0) hat (0)

questions.title: Item 16. Write a dictated sentence: I can stop now.
questions.topInstructionsHTML: When he is done, Jack will say, “I can stop now.” Write the sentence I can stop now (point to line 16).

criteria.guidelines:
The words must be in the correct sequence.

Added words are acceptable, but omitted words are penalized.

Clear spaces are required between the words.

Correct
I can sp naw.
 
Incorrect Explanation
i KAnSOTP nAu KAn and SOTP are not separated by a space
criteria.title: Word Sequence

criteria.guidelines:
first word must be capitalized

Correct
ICOSOPRA
I can sp naw.
 
Incorrect
i KAnSOTP nAu
criteria.title: Capitalization

criteria.guidelines: period or exclamation point at end of sentence
criteria.title: Punctuation

criteria.guidelines:
Correct
I ken stop naw.
I kan stap nio.
 
 
Incorrect
I can sp naw.
I kan sop no.
criteria.title: Phonetically Readable

questions.title: Item 17. Write name
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Place WE Booklet Level 2, Pam and Don’s Adventure, in front of the examinee, and make sure he or
she has a pencil. Point to the first page of the story and say,

This is a story about Pam the Piano and Don the Drum. As we go through the story, you’ll get to write some of the letters, words, and sentences. Write the best words and sentences you can. Don’t worry if you don’t know how to spell a word—spelling doesn’t count.

Let’s start by writing your full name here (point).

If the examinee writes only his or her first name, say, Write your last name, too.

criteria.guidelines:
Disregard capitalization, minor spelling errors, and letter reversals.

To be considered phonetically readable, the examinee’s name must contain more than a single letter.

2 points: phonetically readable first and last name

Hannah (1) Larsen (1)

Sam (1) Hong (1)

Josie (1) Martins (1)

Travis (1) Rylander (1)

Maria (1) Olson (1)

​

  

1 point: phonetically readable first or last name only

Alysha (1)

Vincent (1)

0 points: neither first nor last name is phonetically readable

Ashton (0)

Bernardo (0)

Augustine (0)

​
criteria.title: Write name

data.generalScoringContent:
Refer to the General Scoring Guide for Levels 2–4 before scoring this level.

Do not penalize for letter reversals.

Fused sentences are acceptable on all items except Item 26.

When scoring Structure, ignore capitalization and punctuation errors. Read the response aloud to yourself to decide what the structure would be if capitalization and punctuation had been done correctly.

  • Don and pam went to the man he sad get out you mack too mutch nose.

This example contains two complete, structurally correct sentences, so the response receives credit for Structure.

questions.title: Item 37. Essay
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Turn to the next page in the story.

Help Pam and Don write a letter to the moving company telling about their adventure. The first part, “Dear ABC Movers,” and the last part, “Sincerely, Pam the Piano and Don the Drum,” are already written for you (point). You will have 5 minutes.

If the examinee writes little or nothing, say, Tell what happened to Pam and Don. Write it here (point).

At the end of 4 minutes (240 seconds), say, You have one minute left.

At the end of 5 minutes (300 seconds), say, Stop.

criteria.guidelines:
Count the number of words and select the associated point button.

Count a contraction as one word.

Count a compound word (e.g., baseball) as one word even if the examinee wrote it as two.

Count incorrectly combined words (e.g., alot, highschool) as the number of words combined, even though the examinee wrote them as one.

Count each abbreviation as one word (e.g., p.s.).

Count interjections (e.g., Wow!).

Count unreadable words.

Do not count a title, The End, or a signature.
criteria.title: Number of Words

criteria.guidelines:
Before attempting to identify the sentences, read through the entire essay; reading it aloud may be helpful.

Count the number of sentences that are not fragments or run-ons and select the associated point button.

Count an interjection as a good sentence.

Do not penalize for an omitted or extra word, unless it creates a fragment.

If there are any places where adding or changing punctuation would create good sentences, make these changes and score the essay with the corrected punctuation.

  • If a sentence is a run-on that could be punctuated as multiple good sentences, make these changes and then count the resulting sentences as good sentences.

  • If there are fused sentences, count them as if they were punctuated correctly.

Pam was not sad we went to a library he kicked us out.
Score as 3 good sentences.

  • If a fragment could be made part of the preceding or subsequent sentence by repunctuation, do so and count the combined sentence as one good sentence.
criteria.title: Number of Good Sentences (not fragments or run-ons)

criteria.guidelines: Count the number of correctly structured compound or complex sentences. Use the corrected punctuation.
criteria.title: Number of Compound or Complex Sentences

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

A subject matter idea comes from the story.

2 points: contains three or more subject matter ideas that make sense. Do not penalize for added elements that arise from the story or have some basis in the story.

1 point: contains one or two subject matter ideas even if loosely related; or, regardless of the number of subject matter ideas, includes some parts that do not make sense.

0 points: does not make sense or is completely off subject.
criteria.title: Subject Matter

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than three ideas.

An idea either (a) comes from the story (i.e., a subject matter idea), or (b) is made up by the examinee.

2 points: each paragraph has a main point and all ideas in the paragraph relate to it.

1 point: each paragraph has a main point and most ideas in the paragraph relate to it.

0 points: no main point, or few or none of the ideas relate to the main point.
criteria.title: Main Point

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole. 

Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than three ideas.

An idea either (a) comes from the story (i.e., a subject matter idea), or (b) is made up by the examinee.

2 points: ideas within each paragraph flow logically one from another.

0 points: most ideas within each paragraph seem to be expressed in random order in relation to each other.
criteria.title: Logical Flow

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

2 points: essay reads as though the examinee thought through what to write before beginning. Evidence of planning can be one or more of the following features:

First, second, last organization

Topic sentence

Reference to the end of the story at the beginning of the essay

Covers entire scope of the story; includes details from beginning, middle, and end

Two or more well-constructed paragraphs

0 points: no evidence of planning.
criteria.title: Planning

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than three ideas.

1 point: refers to events from more than one section of the story, in correct sequence.

0 points: refers to events from only one section of the story, or events are out of sequence.
criteria.title: Sequence

questions.title: Item 38. Write name
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Place WE Booklet Level 3, Kyra’s Dragon, in front of the examinee, and make sure he or she has a
pencil. Point to the first page of the story and say,

This is a story about a girl named Kyra and the dragon she has to find. As we go through the story, you’ll get to write some of the words and sentences. Write the best words and sentences you can. Don’t worry if you don’t know how to spell a word—spelling doesn’t count.

Let’s start by writing your full name here (point).

If the examinee writes only his or her first name, say, Write your last name, too.

criteria.guidelines:
Disregard capitalization, minor spelling errors, and letter reversals.

2 points: phonetically readable first and last name

Hannah (1) Larsen (1)

Sam (1) Hong (1)

Josie (1) Martins (1)

Travis (1) Rylander (1)

Maria (1) Olson (1)

  

1 point: phonetically readable first or last name only

Alysha (1)

Vincent (1)

0 points: neither first nor last name is phonetically readable

Ashton (0)

Bernardo (0)

Augustine (0)
criteria.title: Write name

data.generalScoringContent:

At Level 3, fused sentences are Structure errors.

questions.title: Item 39. Write a dictated sentence: The dragon carries people away.
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Turn to the next page in the story.

I’ll say the next sentence and you write it here (point). 

The dragon carries people away.

Repeat the sentence as necessary.

criteria.guidelines:
Words need not be spelled correctly, but they must be recognizable.

1 point: phonetically readable

0 points: not phonetically readable
criteria.title: Phonetically Readable

criteria.guidelines: period or exclamation point at end of sentence
criteria.title: Punctuation

questions.title: Item 56. Essay
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Once all the villagers are safe, they thank the dragon and celebrate with a feast in their new town. 

Turn to the next page in the story.

Pretend you’re the king’s scribe. Retell the story of Kyra’s dragon so that your grandchildren will know how people came to live in their new town. Write it here (point). You will have 10 minutes.

At the end of 9 minutes (540 seconds), say, You have one minute left.

At the end of 10 minutes (600 seconds), say, Stop.

If the examinee stops before 10 minutes (600 seconds) have passed, say, Do you want to write some more? If the examinee says, “No,” stop testing and go on to the next subtest.

criteria.guidelines:
Count the number of words and select the associated point button.

Count a contraction as one word.

Count a compound word (e.g., baseball) as one word even if the examinee wrote it as two.

Count incorrectly combined words (e.g., alot, highschool) as the number of words combined, even though the examinee wrote them as one.

Count each abbreviation as one word (e.g., p.s.).

Count interjections (e.g., Wow!).

Count unreadable words.

Do not count a title, The End, or a signature.
criteria.title: Number of Words

criteria.guidelines:
Before attempting to identify the sentences, read through the entire essay; reading it aloud may be helpful.

Count the number of sentences that are not fragments or run-ons and select the associated point button.

Count an interjection as a good sentence.

Do not penalize for an omitted or extra word, unless it creates a fragment.

If there are any places where adding or changing punctuation would create good sentences, make these changes and score the essay with the corrected punctuation.

  • If a sentence is a run-on that could be punctuated as multiple good sentences, make these changes and then count the resulting sentences as good sentences.

  • If there are fused sentences, count them as if they were punctuated correctly.

    I came here to ask where the dragon is go down that path.
    Score as 2 good sentences.

  • If a fragment could be made part of the preceding or subsequent sentence by repunctuation, do so and count the combined sentence as one good sentence.
criteria.title: Number of Good Sentences (not fragments or run-ons)

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

A subject matter idea comes from the story.

2 points: contains three or more subject matter ideas that make sense. Do not penalize for added elements that arise from the story or have some basis in the story.

1 point: contains one or two subject matter ideas even if loosely related; or, regardless of the number of subject matter ideas, includes some parts that do not make sense.

0 points: does not make sense or is completely off subject.
criteria.title: Subject Matter

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than two sentences.

2 points: first sentence is an explicitly stated setting or summary.

Once upon a time, there was a girl named Kyra.

1 point: first sentence describes the first event.

The king asked Kyra to find the dragon.

0 points: first sentence does not provide a setting or describe the first event.

They went to the old lady to find out what to do.
criteria.title: Introductory Sentence

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than three ideas.

An idea either (a) comes from the story (i.e., a subject matter idea), or (b) is made up by the examinee.

2 points: each paragraph has a main point and all ideas in the paragraph relate to it.

1 point: each paragraph has a main point and most ideas in the paragraph relate to it.

0 points: no main point, or few or none of the ideas relate to the main point.
criteria.title: Main Point

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than three ideas.

An idea either (a) comes from the story (i.e., a subject matter idea), or (b) is made up by the examinee.

2 points: ideas within each paragraph flow logically one from another.

0 points: most ideas within each paragraph seem to be expressed in random order in relation to each other.
criteria.title: Logical Flow

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

2 points: essay reads as though the examinee thought through what to write before beginning. Evidence of planning can be one or more of the following features:

First, second, last organization

Topic sentence

Reference to the end of the story at the beginning of the essay

Covers entire scope of the story; includes details from beginning, middle, and end

Two or more well-constructed paragraphs

0 points: no evidence of planning.
criteria.title: Planning

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than three ideas.

1 point: refers to events from more than one section of the story, in correct sequence.

0 points: refers to events from only one section of the story, or events are out of sequence.
criteria.title: Sequence

questions.title: Item 58. Add capitalization and punctuation
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
You are asked to edit a news release. Add punctuation marks where they are needed, and circle the letters that should be capitalized.

Read the following paragraph aloud:

These are the four main characters: Lucia, Michael, Grace, and Dr. Jonas. In the first scene, Lucia can’t start the spaceship’s back-up control system. She tells Dr. Jonas that they must have the ship ready by exactly 10:00 a.m. What happens next? You’ll have to see the movie.

Go ahead.

If necessary, say, Add punctuation marks where they are needed, and circle the letters that should be capitalized.

criteria.guidelines: Give credit if the examinee uses a semicolon instead of a period and does not capitalize In.

questions.title: Item 59. Write a sentence using target words: in spite of
questions.topInstructionsHTML: You are impressed that the child actors remember their lines so well. Write a sentence to the director complimenting the young actors on their talent. Use the words in spite of (point to the client device) in your sentence.

criteria.guidelines:
In spite of means “regardless of.”

Correct
In spite of their youth they remember their lines.
In spite of all the toys and distractions, the young actors did a great job learning their lines.
The actors did well remembering they’re lines in spite of their lack of focus.
In spite of the young age of these actors, they have a great skill in memorizing their lines.
I was very impressed by the actors’ ability to memorize their lines in spite of their youth.
The kids remember their lines better in spite of all the school work.
In spite of the difficult lines, the young actors did well.
I’m impressed with the young actors in spite of their age.
In spite of difficult lines the young actors performed well.
 
Incorrect Explanation
In spite of the kids are doing very will at momorizing their lines. Uses in spite of incorrectly
In spite of the young actors and actresses doing so well that this movie will be a hit. Does not make sense
In spite their youth they remember their lines. Does not include all required words: In spite used for In spite of
criteria.title: Task: a single sentence that uses in spite of correctly, includes two contrasting ideas generally related to the child actors and their work, and makes sense

criteria.guidelines:
Incorrect Explanation
In spite their youth they remember their lines. Omitted word
In spite of the young actors and actresses doing so well that this movie will be a hit. Fragment
Hey, Dave nice work on the cast in spite of there age they’re great thanks. Fused sentences
In spite of knowing their lines well, they are very young Incorrect word order (They are not young in spite of knowing their lines well; rather, they know their lines well in spite of being young.)
They do good in spite of being young. Incorrect part of speech

questions.title: Item 61. Write a sentence that combines three ideas without “and”
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Turn to the next page in the story.

The ad agency wants some inside information about the film. Write one sentence that includes all of these ideas:

you’ll want to see it twice, full of suspense, an amazing journey

Write one sentence including all of these ideas. Don’t use the word and in your sentence.

criteria.guidelines:
Correct
This is a movie that you’ll want to see twice; it is an amazing journey full of suspense.
Because it is an amazing journey, full of suspense, you’ll want to see it twice.
It is an amazing journey that is so full of suspense that you’ll want to see it twice.
It is an amazing journey that is full of suspense that you’ll want to see twice.
 
Incorrect Explanation
This movie is so full of suspense that you’ll want to see it twice. Missing one idea
Its such an amazing journey that you wants to see it twice. Missing one idea
you’ll want to see it twice, full of suspense, of course an amazing journey Does not make sense
criteria.title: Task: a single sentence that does not include and, generally refers to three ideas (seeing the film twice, suspense, and an amazing journey), and makes sense

criteria.guidelines:
Correct Explanation
Because it is an amazing journey, you’ll want to see the movie twice. Not including all 3 ideas is not penalized under Structure
 
Incorrect Explanation
You’ll want to see it twice, it’s full of suspense, plus it’s an amazing journey. Fused sentences
Come see an amazing journey that’s full of suspense, you will have to see it twice. Fused sentences
you’ll want to see it twice, full of suspense, of course an amazing journey Fused sentences and fragments
The amazing journey is full of suspense so you’ll want to see it twice. Not complex because so is a coordinating conjunction
This movie is an amazing journey that you’ll want to see it twice because it’s full of suspense. Extra word

criteria.guidelines:

You’ll want to see this movie twice, because it’s full of suspense.
You’ll want to see this movie twice because it’s full of suspense.

Its such an amazing journey that you wants to see it twice. Subject-verb disagreement

questions.title: Item 62. Write a sentence using a target word: which
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
The director asks you to write an answer to this fan letter:

Dear Mr. Director,
Will you tell me what movie is your favorite?
Signed,
A Fan

The director’s note says, “saw Night of Nights as a kid—loved it!”

Based on his note, write one good sentence to the fan. Use the word which in your sentence.

criteria.guidelines:
Correct
As a child I saw Night of Nights, which I loved.
I saw Night of Nights, which I loved, when I was a kid.
My favorite movie is Night of Nights, which I saw as a kid.
 
Incorrect Explanation
I saw night of nights as a kid and I loved it. Omitted target word
I saw Night of Nights as a kid which I loved it. Uses which incorrectly
I’m going with a band on tour, which will be a lot of fun. Does not address the question
Which movie is your favorite? Does not address the question
It’s a great movie, I love the part where the witch comes in. Does not address the question; omitted target word
criteria.title: Task: a single sentence that uses which correctly, responds to the question “What is your favorite movie?,” and makes sense

criteria.guidelines:
Correct
As a child I saw Night of Nights, which I loved.
I saw Night of Nights, which I loved, when I was a kid.
My favorite movie is Night of Nights, which I saw as a kid.
 
Incorrect Explanation
I saw Night of Nights as a kid, which I loved and still watch to this day. Incorrect word order (modifier [which] cannot easily be linked to what it modifies [Night of Nights])
It’s a great movie, I love the part where the witch comes in. Fused sentences
My favorite is Night of Nights, which is your favorite? Fused sentences; not complex
Which movie is your favorite? Not complex

questions.title: Item 64. Write a sentence that combines three ideas

You are writing a report for the budget meeting. Here are your notes:

most sets are finished, still need to hire composer, good composers cost a lot of money

questions.title: Item 66. Write a sentence that connects existing sentences
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
In the movie, Dr. Jonas gives a speech about time travel. Here is part of his speech:

The way we travel has changed greatly over the years. At one time, people couldn’t imagine flying through the air in a plane. (Pause, point to blank.) Someday, time travel will be just as commonplace.

Write one good sentence to complete this paragraph.

criteria.guidelines:
Examples of transitional words include now, nowadays, today, and yet.

Correct
Today we have planes that travel to all parts of the world in a matter of hours.
But nowadays almost everyone travels by airplane when traveling a long distance.
 
Incorrect Explanation
We travel by air and even in space. Does not provide a transitional word or phrase
We go wherever we want. Does not provide a transitional word or phrase
Now we travel in space Does not logically connect sentences: space travel is not commonplace
But now we travel in planes all the time, and soon we’ll have time travel. Does not logically connect to the following sentence printed in the booklet: reference to time travel
But of course now we can travel in space and soon time. Does not logically connect sentences
criteria.title: Task: one or more sentences that provides an appropriate transitional word or phrase and a logical connection between the existing sentences, and makes sense

criteria.guidelines:

If the examinee does not change the end punctuation or initial capitalization appropriately, score 0 for Structure.

Incorrect Explanation
But now look at us, we’re flying everywhere. Fused sentences
Or flying into space. Fragment

Correct

Incorrect Explanation

questions.title: Item 67. Essay
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Your school newspaper wants you to write a short article about your day on the set of Lost in Time. Write it here. You can continue on the back page if you wish. You will have 10 minutes.

At the end of 9 minutes (540 seconds), say, You have one minute left.

At the end of 10 minutes (600 seconds), say, Stop.

If the examinee stops before 10 minutes (600 seconds) have passed, say, Do you want to write some more? If the examinee says, “No,” stop testing and go on to the next subtest.

criteria.guidelines:
Count the number of words and select the associated point button.

Count a contraction as one word.

Count a compound word (e.g., baseball) as one word even if the examinee wrote it as two.

Count incorrectly combined words (e.g., alot, highschool) as the number of words combined, even though the examinee wrote them as one.

Count each abbreviation as one word (e.g., p.s.).

Count interjections (e.g., Wow!).

Count unreadable words.

Do not count a title, The End, or a signature.
criteria.title: Number of Words

criteria.guidelines:
Before attempting to identify the sentences, read through the entire essay; reading it aloud may be helpful.

Count the number of sentences that are not fragments or run-ons and select the associated point button.

Count an interjection (Wow!) as a good sentence.

Do not penalize for an omitted or extra word, unless it creates a fragment.

If there are any places where adding or changing punctuation would create good sentences, make these changes and score the essay with the corrected punctuation.

  • If a sentence is a run-on that could be punctuated as multiple good sentences, make these changes and then count the resulting sentences as good sentences.

  • If there are fused sentences, count them as if they were punctuated correctly.

    I came here to ask where the roses go put them there.
    Score as 2 good sentences.

  • If a fragment could be made part of the preceding or subsequent sentence by repunctuation, do so and count the combined sentence as one good sentence.
criteria.title: Number of Good Sentences (not fragments or run-ons)

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

A subject matter idea comes from the story.

2 points: contains three or more subject matter ideas that make sense. Do not penalize for added elements that arise from the story or have some basis in the story.

1 point: contains one or two subject matter ideas even if loosely related; or, regardless of the number of subject matter ideas, includes some parts that do not make sense.

0 points: does not make sense or is completely off subject.
criteria.title: Subject Matter

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

1 point: demonstrates involvement in the story and a sense of audience by writing in character as though writing an article for a school newspaper after visiting a movie set.

0 points: takes on a different persona or does not take on any point of view.
criteria.title: Involvement

criteria.guidelines:
Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than two sentences.

2 points: first sentence is an explicitly stated setting or summary.

Yesterday, I had the opportunity to spend the day on the set of Lost in Time.

1 point: first sentence describes the first event.

When I first got to the set, no one was there.

0 points: first sentence does not provide a setting or describe the first event.

I got to see kids practicing lines.
criteria.title: Introductory Sentence

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than three sentences.

1 point: at least one sentence is significantly different from the others in length, or it has a different structure.

0 points: all sentences are similar in length and structure.
criteria.title: Varied Sentence Structure

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than three ideas.

An idea either (a) comes from the story (i.e., a subject matter idea), or (b) is made up by the examinee.

2 points: each paragraph has a main point and all ideas in the paragraph relate to it.

1 point: each paragraph has a main point and most ideas in the paragraph relate to it.

0 points: no main point, or few or none of the ideas relate to the main point.
criteria.title: Main Point

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

Score 0 if the essay contains fewer than three ideas.

An idea either (a) comes from the story (i.e., a subject matter idea), or (b) is made up by the examinee.

2 points: ideas within each paragraph flow logically one from another.

0 points: most ideas within each paragraph seem to be expressed in random order in relation to each other.
criteria.title: Logical Flow

criteria.guidelines:
Consider the essay as a whole.

2 points: essay reads as though the examinee thought through what to write before beginning. Evidence of planning can be one or more of the following features:

First, second, last organization

Topic sentence

Reference to the end of the story at the beginning of the essay

Covers entire scope of the story; includes details from beginning, middle, and end

Two or more well-constructed paragraphs

0 points: no evidence of planning.
criteria.title: Planning

htmlSnippets.GenScoringGuide2-4:
This section provides general scoring guidelines and an explanation of the error categories for Levels 2–4. Guidance for scoring the essay (story retelling) items is not included here; all information required for scoring the essays is included in the item-specific scoring rules for each of these levels.

Scoring Rationale

The purpose of Written Expression at Levels 2–4 is to measure the examinee’s ability to communicate his or her ideas on paper and to assess the quality of the written responses. Spelling is not scored. 

The Written Expression scoring rules require that responses follow standard rules of grammar unless otherwise indicated. However, grammar is not necessarily scored to the highest level of editorial accuracy. Generally, the grammatical errors that are penalized would stand out in semiformal or formal communication, such as speaking to the class or writing a report.

General Scoring Guidelines

Each item has one or more score categories, and each is scored 0, 1, or 2 points. Score each category independently of the others. Try not to let poor performance in one category influence the scores for other categories in that item. 

Sometimes a response is clearly erroneous, but it is not immediately evident which category/ies should be scored 0. In those instances, use your judgment to choose the category/ies that best fits the error.

Some errors result in scores of 0 across multiple or all categories:

  • If an examinee does not respond to an item or if the response is incomprehensible, score 0 on all categories for that item.
  • On later items, misplacement of a part of the sentence is penalized on both the Task criterion (because the sentence does not make sense or says something false) and the Structure criterion (because of the misplacement). In such cases, score 0 for both criteria.

Scoring Extra Writing

If the Task criterion specifies a limited response (e.g., one word or one sentence), and the examinee produces a response, part of which satisfies this criterion, ignore any additional material the examinee has written when scoring that item. 

If the Task criterion is open-ended (e.g., one or more sentences), score the entire response. For the Structure criterion, scoring usually is based on the examinee’s entire response, except when the scoring rule for an item specifies otherwise.

Readability of Responses

If a response is difficult to read due to poor spelling or poor handwriting, score as much of it as possible.

Scoring Guidelines for Phonetically Readable Words

Phonetically readable is not a technical term; it means that all sounds in the word are represented and in the correct sequence even if the word is not spelled correctly. Missing letters, poor letter formation, letter reversals, and upside-down or sideways letters are acceptable as long as the word is recognizable.

Scoring Guidelines for Recognizable Letters

Poor letter formation, letter reversals, and upside-down or sideways letters are acceptable as long as the letter is recognizable and does not form another letter. Accept upper- or lowercase letters or a mix.

Explanation of Error Categories

TASK

Task refers to whether the response is on topic; makes sense; correctly uses required words, phrases, or ideas; and follows all other instructions.

STRUCTURE

Sentence structure has to do with the organization of the sentence as a whole. Some items allow fused sentences, but others do not. Some items require a particular kind of structure.

If the examinee uses a word that is incorrect in meaning but is the correct part of speech for the way the sentence is structured, score as a Word Form error rather than a Structure error. If in doubt, try substituting a different word that is of the same part of speech.

Structure errors include the following:

Fragment

Missing the subject or verb

Making too much noise.

A TV studio with desks and lights and cameras.

Fused Sentence

One or more independent clauses not separated by appropriate punctuation or a connecting word, or separated only by a comma

Score a fused sentence as a Structure error except on some Level 2 items where indicated.

Nicole lost her script do you have it.

Nicole lost her script, do you have it.

Run-On Sentence

Three or more clauses, joined by conjunctions, whose ideas are not closely linked

We see the ants but there bigger and the chase us and Emily starts writeing.

My favorite movie is Night of Nights and I saw it as a kid and I loved it but I want to know which movie is your favorite.

Rome looks at all the rocks and Emily jumps up and down and while Emily is jumping Rome is looking at the rocks.

Incorrect Word Order

Misplaced parts of sentence: modifier cannot easily be linked to the word it modifies

Incorrect: Ramón is on the moon who is looking at rocks.

Correct: Ramón, who is looking at rocks, is on the moon.

Incorrect: Rita is going home, who lives in another neighborhood.

Correct: Rita, who lives in another neighborhood, is going home.

Incorrect: In spite of knowing their lines well, they are very young.

Correct: In spite of being very young, they know their lines well.

Confusion between direct and implied questions: sentence starts as a statement and ends as a question

I’m wondering if you know where is the director’s chair?

The director wants to know where is his chair?

I wonder where are we going?

Nicole wants to know where is her script?

If the examinee combines a direct question with an implied question and does not indicate through quotation marks or other punctuation that it is a quotation, score 0 for Structure.

Kyra asks why are you hurting people.

Extra Word

Sentence could be corrected by removing a word

Nicole wants to know so where her script is.

The girl dropped her toy, and Matt, he picked it up.

Omitted Word

Sentence could be corrected by inserting a word

The teacher is and the children are glad.

He is telling to be quiet.

Incorrect Part of Speech

Most commonly, this error occurs when an adjective is used in place of an adverb and is intended to function as an adverb.

Incorrect: In spite of their youth, the actors did great remembering their lines.

Correct: In spite of their youth, the actors did well remembering their lines.

Incorrect: Even though they were excited, some kids sat quiet so others could sleep.

Correct: Even though they were excited, some kids sat quietly so others could sleep.

Did not identify the subject when the verb form changed

Incorrect: Nicole wants to know where her script is and is asking the man next to her.

Correct: Nicole wants to know where her script is and she is asking the man next to her.

PUNCTUATION

At Level 2, score only for end punctuation and for apostrophes in contractions and possessives.

At Levels 3 and 4, score all types of punctuation.

When scoring a fused sentence, do not penalize for lack of ending punctuation where the first independent clause ends.

Apostrophe

An apostrophe is required in contractions and possessives, and prohibited everywhere else.

Possessives: Kyra’s dragon, Marty’s picture, all stars’ needs, his officers’ safety

Contractions: can’t, won’t, isn’t, shouldn’t

Comma

Exclamation Point

An exclamation point should be used to show emphasis or excitement. In most instances, an exclamation point is acceptable in place of a period at the end of a sentence.

Hyphen

Hyphenation of compound adjectives is ignored in scoring.

scary-looking dragon
htmlSnippets.comma:
Score comma usage liberally. In situations not covered by the following rules, do not penalize comma usage unless the presence or absence of the comma makes the sentence ambiguous, difficult to understand, or misleading. 

Some comma usage is governed by clear rules, as listed below. In many other instances, however, acceptable comma usage is variable.

A comma is required

  • In a series of two or more adjectives or nouns

If the adjectives are not interchangeable in sequence and they cannot be correctly separated
by and, a comma should not be used:

I see a large, empty set.

The dinosaur has four sharp prongs on its tail.

I see dinosaurs, mountains, and shrubs.

I see dinosaurs, mountains and shrubs. (The comma before the conjunction and is optional, and
it has been omitted in this example.)

  • When providing dates and place names

May 2, 2004, is the release date.

Brooklyn, New York, is home to the crew.

  • Before or after titles of address

Dear Director, (either a comma or colon is acceptable)

I see the cave, Mr. Feathers.

Prop Department, do you have the director’s chair?

  • After conjunctive adverbs

However, the frequent changes in anchors can be distracting.

Actually, he never attended acting school.

  • After mild interjections or one-word commands

Well, what are you drawing now?

Look, my script is missing.

  • To set off direct quotations

Nicole said, “Have you seen my script?”

“My script,” Nicole said, “is missing.”

Nicole said, “Where is my script?”

  • After a subordinate clause and before a main clause when the subordinate clause is at the beginning of the sentence

Although they were tired, the crew did a good job.

  • To indicate a nonessential clause

Night of Nights, which I saw as a kid, is my favorite movie.

A comma is optional

  • After introductory elements

Despite the weather, the crew did a great job.

Despite the weather the crew did a great job.

  • After a main clause and before a coordinating conjunction (and, but, or, for, so, nor, yet)

Emily jumps, and Ramón looks at rocks.

Emily jumps and Ramón looks at rocks.

  • Before a subordinating conjunction when the subordinate clause is at the end of the sentence

My job is fulfilling, although the deadlines are stressful.

My job is fulfilling although the deadlines are stressful.
htmlSnippets.capitalization:
On items that ask the examinee to circle letters that should be capitalized, circling the entire word rather than the first letter or using a double underline or other such indication is acceptable.

In general, consider a capital letter to be an indication that the examinee intended to start a new sentence, but exercise judgment in making this decision.

If an examinee’s handwriting style uses mostly uppercase letters, give credit for correct capitalization unless there are obvious errors.

When scoring a fused sentence, do not penalize for lack of capitalization where the second independent clause begins.

The following words must be capitalized.

  • First word of a sentence

  • Proper nouns

  • Days of the week, months of the year

  • Book or movie titles

  • Titles of address

Your Majesty (but the king)

Mayor Martin (but the mayor)

  • The next word(s) following a salutation

Dear Ad Agency

The next word following a form of address (e.g., King) may or may not be capitalized.

Capitalization is prohibited

  • for any word that does not fit one of the above categories

  • following a semicolon
htmlSnippets.questionmark:
Question Mark

A question mark is required after a direct question and prohibited after an implied question.

  • Direct Questions

Incorrect: Where is the director’s chair.

Correct: Where is the director’s chair?

  • Implied Questions

Incorrect: I’m wondering if you know the location of the director’s chair?

Correct: I’m wondering if you know the location of the director’s chair.

Incorrect: The director wants to know where his chair is?

Correct: The director wants to know where his chair is.
htmlSnippets.semicolon:
Semicolon

If the examinee correctly uses a semicolon in an item calling for just one sentence, consider it to be one sentence.
htmlSnippets.wordform:
Word form errors involve the form (tense, agreement, plurality) or usage of a word.

When scoring Word Form, do not penalize for the following.

  • That vs. which: in contexts where these words serve a broadly similar function, accept either as correct.

  • A vs. an: incorrect articles are considered spelling errors and are not penalized.

  • Your vs. you’re: writing your instead of you’re, or vice versa, is considered a spelling error and is not penalized.

  • There vs. their vs. they’re: writing the wrong form of there, their, or they’re is considered a spelling error and is not penalized.

  • It’s vs. its: Writing it’s vs. its, or vice versa, is considered a spelling error and is not penalized.
htmlSnippets.slang:
Slang terminology, nonstandard usages such as anyways for anyway and alls for all that, and nonstandard contractions such as gonna, woulda, and ain’t

Do not penalize for use of ‘til, which is an acceptable contraction for until.
htmlSnippets.subject-verb:
Subjects and verbs disagree in number (singular, plural) or person (first, second, third)

They is going into the library.

After she get her popcorn, she trip.
htmlSnippets.incorrectverbform:
Wrong verb tense or wrong form of a verb

She telled them to go.

He blowed up the toy.

I am go to bring a pencil so that we can get back home.

She buyed the T-shirt.

He don’t got a shirt.

I ain’t going.
htmlSnippets.parallelstructure:
Verb tense changes inappropriately within a sentence

While they played music, people talk.

The girl finally picks up the script that had been laying there.
htmlSnippets.incorrectvarious:
• A singular noun is used where a plural is needed

Where are all the chair?

Broadcasting from the Olympics will increase rating and support local athlete.

  • Incorrect pronoun

Her and him are walking together.

The dragon scared they two.

  • Unclear pronoun referent

The boy and her mom are looking at birds.

After she got her popcorn, a scooter was in her way and she dropped it.

  • Possessive noun or pronoun case is not used where it should be

They are going to put little Marty picture in the book.

He picked up the little girl toy.

Do not penalize for the following pronouns:

  • Using that to refer to a person

She was the one that fed the cat.

  • Using they or their to refer to a single person

A child is doing their homework.
htmlSnippets.incorrectpreposition: The girl is looking at the pictures with the book. (with should be in)
htmlSnippets.wordmeaning:
Using the wrong word for the context or nonwords

Incorrect part of speech is a Structure error, not a Word Form error.

She was besides the mirror. (besides is used to mean beside)

The girl waters my worst favorite flowers. (worst should be least)

Unless you don’t help, I will have to carry all the laundry. (unless is used to mean if )
htmlSnippets.doublenegativealltheway:
Two negative words cancel each other out

I don’t want to go to no news station.

She don’t want no more.

htmlSnippets.otherMechErrors:
Score 0 for No Other Mechanical Errors if the examinee responded to the item with “don’t know” or no response, or made a capitalization or punctuation error not already covered elsewhere within the scoring criteria. Errors may include the following.

  • Lack of capitalization of the first word of a sentence or a proper noun
    ​
  • Words or letters within a sentence inappropriately capitalized
    ​
  • Apostrophes in verbs, plural nouns, or possessive pronouns
    ​
  • Incorrect insertion or omission of quotation marks, commas, periods, or semicolons
